solution_line_template: If Pete walks on hands at {pete_hands_fraction} what Tracy can do 1-handed cartwheels, then Tracy can do 1-handed cartwheels at {pete_hands_speed}*{tracy_multiplier}={tracy_cartwheel_speed} miles per hour.

Since Tracy does 1-handed cartwheels twice the rate of Susan's forward walking, then Susan walks at {tracy_cartwheel_speed}/{tracy_susan_speed_ratio}=<<{tracy_cartwheel_speed}/{tracy_susan_speed_ratio}={susan_forward_speed}>>{susan_forward_speed} miles per hour.
Pete walks backwards {pete_susan_speed_ratio}x faster than Susan walks forward, and thus Pete walks backwards at {susan_forward_speed}*{pete_susan_speed_ratio}={pete_backwards_speed} miles per hour.
